Award.AwardTitle: Broadening the Reach of Engineering through Community Engagement (BRECE)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Broadening the Reach of Engineering through Community Engagement (BRECE) Scholars Program provides 4 years of mentoring, academic and financial support to a cohort of 13 financially-challenged and academically-talented students to pursue engineering baccalaureate degrees in the College of Technology and Innovation at Arizona State University. The BRECE scholars program is creating a cohort of socially responsible engineering graduates who are able to apply their engineering training to a broader range of STEM fields including teaching, social entrepreneurship, public service, non-profit and other community engagement areas. The application of engineering to help society serves to attract and retain a broader population of students, particularly those with financial need who wish to help their communities.

Traditionally, community engagement has not been a prominent aspect of engineering education. In fact, engineering students are reported to be more likely than students in other disciplines to believe that individuals cannot create change in society and less likely to describe themselves as altruistic. ASU calls on all who reside within the institution to share the responsibility for the economic, social and cultural vitality of the communities that surround it. The BRECE Scholars Program represents an exemplary case of a holistic educational approach towards nurturing socially responsible engineers; utilizing both curricular and co-curricular activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Broadening the Reach of Engineering through Community Engagement (BRECE) Scholars Program provided up to 4 years of mentoring, academic and financial support to cohorts of financially challenged and academically talented students to pursue and earn engineering baccalaureate degrees in the Polytechnic School at Arizona State University (ASU). Two years involve domestic community engagement related to STEAM outreach and two years concentrate on international communities, specifically in the developing world. As part of the program, scholars received academic support services, participated in community building and meeting events, went on field trips and conducted outreach activities to support recruitment, received mentoring from faculty, and optionally participated in research projects related to engineering education and global development.

The STEAM Labs? Center for K-12 Research and Engagement promotes the integration of Science, Technology, Engineering, Math, and the Arts in education. Much of the outreach work done through STEAM Labs™ involves curriculum and activities to engage middle- and high-school aged students in the engineering design and construction of chain-reaction machines.

BRECE Scholars first engaged in training on how to make, spending time learning how to build things in on-campus makerspaces. Simultaneously, they planned and executed a number of community-facing STEM/STEAM outreach events where they not only executed the activities that they had developed but also engaged the community to make and engineer as well. BRECE Scholars designed and ran activities for a number of outreach events (e.g., ASU?s Night of the Open Door, the Southwest Maker Fest, Girls Have IT Day, Arizona Science Center CREATE makerspace opening, Spring Training Festival, ASU?s Discover E-Day), engaged with donors, hosted chain reaction machine contests and hackathons on campus, worked with futurists to design a Rube Goldberg escape room experience for the EMERGE festival at ASU, exhibited at a large-scale chain reaction booth at the Bay Area Maker Faire, judged the Navajo Nation Science Fair, and designed and built their own chain-reaction machines to showcase to the public. They impacted thousands of children over the duration of the project, providing fun, project-based engagement with STEM and STEAM.

As a result of these engagements, Scholars not only impacted thousands of children through project-based STEM and STEAM activities but also developed management, leadership, and planning skills that when crossed with social responsibility created a sense of meaning and purpose for them as engineers. Two BRECE graduates are now pursuing PhDs in engineering and STEM education.

GlobalResolve is a social entrepreneurship program at ASU with two goals: 1) Empower students to make a difference in the world and 2) Reduce the effects of poverty in underserved communities in the Global South. The use of GlobalResolve in the BRECE program was seen as a good match since the goal of BRECE was to "create a cohort of socially responsible graduates who are able to apply their engineering training to a broader range of fields that can include teaching, social entrepreneurship, public service, non-profit and other community engagement areas".  

BRECE students traveled with GlobalResolve projects to Nepal, South Pacific and Kenya.  Each of the students who chose to participate had a unique experience. SolarSPELL students developed curriculum content and taught Peace Corps volunteers how to use the Learning Library.  Students to Nepal did home stays near Chitwan National Park and taught the community how to make biochar and also installed a solar-powered irrigation system.  The students in Kenya identified several projects at MERC (Maasai Education, Research and Conservation Institute) where they stayed along with students from Prescott College. Projects included: solar power installation, water purification, composting, garden development, water pumping, recycling, waste management, curriculum development, teaching elementary students and the most ambitious which is still continuing is to provide an auto maintenance and repair facility along with mechanic training for long term economic development and job creation. Several of the BRECE students have chosen global development as graduate programs for further education. One student has returned 3 times for longer periods funded by a USAID grant and is pursuing a PhD in global development.  

In summary, the BRECE Scholars Program is an exemplar of a holistic educational approach towards nurturing socially responsible engineers. As community engagement has not traditionally been a prominent aspect of engineering education, this program has helped to transform the career paths of engineering students by fostering social responsibility in the context of a broad range of STEM careers (teachers, social entrepreneurs, public service, nonprofit, community). A significant impact on the Scholars themselves is how they now think differently about engineering in the context of the world we live in.
